function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Aerosolised viruses appear to be more vulnerable to UV damage than when they are suspended in a liquid or on a substrate.","Impact":"Greater difficulty in disinfecting viruses suspended in liquid compared to those suspended in air, leading to higher risk of transmission.","Mitigation":"Implement targeted UV-C disinfection methods for viruses suspended in liquid.","Technologies":"UV-C disinfection systems for liquid suspension.","People":"Individuals in built environments with high risk of virus transmission.","Owner":"Facility managers, public health authorities, and building owners."},{"Description":"Irradiating the coronavirus in liquid requires a UV-C dose that is in the region 1.8-6.0 times higher than that required when the virus is suspended in air.","Impact":"Higher UV-C dose requirement for liquid suspension increases the difficulty in virus disinfection.","Mitigation":"Develop UV-C dose calibration methods specifically for liquid suspension scenarios.","Technologies":"Calibrated UV-C dose measurement systems for liquid suspension.","People":"Research institutions, public health laboratories, and disinfection equipment manufacturers.","Owner":"Regulatory agencies, research institutions, and disinfection equipment manufacturers."},{"Description":"The adjustment coefficient c_ur for UV-C dose when the virus is suspended in air may be in a range 0.167-0.545.","Impact":"Uncertainty in the adjustment coefficient may lead to improper UV-C dosing and ineffective virus disinfection.","Mitigation":"Conduct extensive research to determine the accurate adjustment coefficient for different virus suspension scenarios.","Technologies":"Laboratory testing equipment for adjustment coefficient determination.","People":"Research scientists, virologists, and public health experts.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations, and regulatory agencies."}]}
